University of New South Wales, Kensington, NSW 2033, Australia bSchool of Chemistry, University of New South Wales, Kensington, NSW 2033, Australia CSchool of Chemistry, Macquarie University, Macquarie, NSW 2109, Australia Received 29 December 1993; revised 31 March 1994; accepted 31 March 1994 Abstract The gas-phase hydrogenolysis of dimethyl succinate (DMS) has been studied over a series of copper- based catalysts at a temperature of 513 K and a pressure of 500 kPa. Using copper chromite and copper on silica, y-butyrolactone (GBL) and methanol were formed in the first step, while GBL reacted further to tetrahydrofuran (THF) and water, Over copper zinc oxide catalysts, THF was mainly formed in a parallel reaction directly from DMS. Additionally, the steam reforming of methanol occurred over these catalysts. No catalyst deactivation with time-on-stream could be detected, but exposure to DMS significantly decreased the copper surface area of all catalysts. The area specific rate for the reaction of dimethyl succinate to y-butyrolactone over copper zinc oxide was one order of magnitude higher than over the other catalysts. The most active catalyst for the subsequent reaction of GBL to tetrahydrofuran was found to be copper chromite. The reaction rates could be described by simple kinetic equations based on a reaction network. Kevwords: Butyrolactone (3'-) Copper; Dimethyl succinate Hydrogenolysis; Tetrahydrofuran 1. Introduction The hydrogenolysis of esters to alcohols over copper catalysts is a well known reaction [ 1 ]. Recently, the liquid- and gas-phase hydrogenolysis of dialkyl esters has been described, mainly in the patent literature, as a potential new route for the synthesis of diols. The formation of butanediol is believed to proceed via T-butyrolactone (Eq. 4), high pressures and low temperatures ther- modynamically favouring BDL production [ 15]. ?H2--CH2~o + 2 H 2 I, HO--(CH2)4--OH (4) CH~--CO / GBL BDL Thus the development of a process with the flexibility to give mixtures of buta- nediol, T-butyrolactone, and tetrahydrofuran in desired proportions seems to be possible. In fact, the gas-phase hydrogenolysis of dialkyl esters has been described as part of a new, cost-effective, butane-based route to butanediol and its derivatives [16]. Previous studies of the hydrogenolysis of dimethyl succinate were carried out using Raney copper catalysts [6,7]. However, in most of the cases described in the patent literature, copper-based catalysts such as copper on silica [ 3,4], copper zinc oxide [ 9 ], and particularly copper chromite [ 2,8,10,11 ] were used for diol pro- duction. In the present paper, the hydrogenolysis of dimethyl succinate was studied over several copper-based catalysts to gain more insight into the role of copper in catalysts used to promote this hydrogenolysis reaction. 2. Catalysts B (ZnO) and C (Cu/ZnO, ncu/nz, = 1:2) were prepared by coprecip- itation from aqueous 1 M nitrate solutions of copper and zinc. Sodium carbonate solution ( 1 M) was added at a rate of 2 ml/min at 353 K to a final pH of 7. The precipitate was filtered and washed, dried at 383 K for 16 h and calcined in air for 1 h at 623 K. Catalyst D ( 'copper chromite' ) was prepared according to the method of Miya et al. [ 18]. Thus, a solution containing 100 g of CuSO4" 5H20 in 300 ml of water was heated to 383 K and added over a 15-min period to a solution of 60 g Na2Cr207 2H20, 260 ml of water and 60 ml of concentrated ammonia solution at ambient temperature. The mixture, which had a temperature of 323 K after addition, was subsequently heated to 353 K and kept there for 1.5 h. The orange precipitate was filtered and washed, dried at 383 K for 16 h and calcined in air at 623 K for 30 min. Catalyst E was a mechanical mixture comprising 50 wt.-% ZnO (catalyst B) and 50 wt.-% copper chromite (catalyst D). Catalyst F was a commercial Cu/ ZnO/AlzO3 methanol synthesis catalyst (BASF $3-85). If necessary, catalyst pow- ders were pressed to tablets, crushed and sieved to obtain the desired fraction. The total surface area of the catalysts was measured using the single point BET technique [ 19] after reduction in hydrogen at 473 K for 2 h. The copper surface areas were determined by nitrous oxide decomposition [20] using a single pulse (0.5 ml) of nitrous oxide at 363 K and assuming a surface density of copper atoms of 1.46.10 t9 atoms/m z. In all experiments, unless otherwise stated, a 210- 500 mm sieve fraction of the catalysts (0.5 to 10.0 g) was used. The fresh catalyst samples were reduced in a flow of hydrogen (50 ml/min) at 473 K for 2 h. The dimethyl succinate feed (Merck, > 97%) was added to the gas feed using an ISCO LC-2600 stainless steel syringe pump and vaporized in an electrically heated stain- less steel preheater. The hydrogen flow-rate was controlled by a Brooks 5850 T. Turek et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 116 (1994) 137-150 thermal mass flow controller. At dimethyl succinate conversions higher than 50%, the water mole fraction decreases while the values for THF increase slightly. At the same time, carbon dioxide is generated. This indicates the occurrence of a further reaction involving water and producing carbon dioxide. The steam reforming of methanol (Eq. 9) seems to be the most likely reason for the consumption of water, given that copper zinc oxide catalysts have been shown to be active for this reaction [ 21 ]. CH3OH + H20 ~ CO2 + 3H2 (9) Furthermore, since the methanol steam reforming has been shown to proceed via methyl formate [22], the presence of traces of methyl formate at high dimethyl succinate conversions over the copper zinc oxide catalysts also indicates that reac- tion (9) takes place. Copper surface areas were also determined after reaction. The reduced BASF copper zinc oxide catalyst is pyrophoric and was therefore carefully passivated with a stream of 1% nitrous oxide in helium at room temperature before exposure to air. Although no catalyst deactivation could be observed during the reaction of dimethyl succinate, the copper surface areas determined after re-reducing the used catalyst samples were significantly lower than the values for the fresh catalysts. On the other hand, BET surface areas remained relatively stable (Table 2). Sintering of copper particles is somewhat unlikely at the low reaction temperature of 513 K. Prolonged hydrogen treatment at 573 K did not increase the measured values. Thus simple blocking of copper by adsorbed species cannot be the reason for the decrease of copper surface area. Overall reaction rates based on the amount of dimethyl succinate converted were related to the copper surface area determined after reaction (Fig. 4). Copper zinc oxide and the commercial BASF methanol synthesis catalyst are about one order of magnitude more active than copper chromite and copper on silica. Pure zinc oxide has a very low hydrogenolysis activity both for pure DMS and a feed having a typical product composition. The mass specific reaction rate over zinc oxide is T. On the other hand, the strong decrease in BET surface area shows that dimethyl succinate interacts with zinc oxide. How- ever, the addition of zinc oxide to copper chromite strongly enhances the catalyst activity. At dimethyl succinate conversions close to unity in particular, catalyst E exhibits reaction rates comparable to those obtained over the coprecipitated copper zinc oxide catalysts. When attention is focused on tetrahydrofuran selectivity as a function of con- version (Fig. 5), the trends for copper chromite, copper on silica and the zinc oxide/copper chromite mixture clearly indicate that the formation of tetrahydrofuran is a subsequent reaction over these catalysts. At dimethyl succinate conversions approaching zero, no THF is formed. In contrast, the copper zinc oxide catalysts C and F show a constant tetrahydrofuran selectivity of around 0.06 even at conversions below 10%. Only at DMS conversions higher than 80% does the THF selectivity reach values significantly higher than 0.1. Thus over copper zinc oxide catalysts, tetrahydrofuran seems to be formed directly from dimethyl succin- ate in a parallel step. The following calculations also support this assumption. On the other hand, the copper zinc oxide catalyst produces THF initially with a much higher rate. At high DMS conversions, the THF formation rate decreases to a level similar to those observed for the other catalysts. Thus over copper zinc oxide, DMS seems to react to GBL and THF in a fixed ratio. When at high DMS conversions the rate of dimethyl succinate conversion, and thus the rate of tetrahydrofuran formation via the parallel step, reaches sufficiently low values, the subsequent reaction of GBL to THF becomes significant and the tetrahydrofuran selectivity can increase to values higher than 0.1. Riekert [ 23 ] has pointed out that, for a set of consecutive reactions, the selectiv- ities with respect to the intermediate and the stable end products are not only a function of residence time in the reactor (i.e. conversion of the starting material) but can also be altered by pore diffusion effects. Even if DMS could only react to GBL in the first place, it might undergo further conversion to THF in the porous catalyst structure, thus causing an apparent direct path from dimethyl succinate to tetrahydrofuran. To exclude this possibility, the tetrahydrofuran selectivity over the BASF catalyst F was determined for two different sieve fractions ( 125 to 150 ~m and 210 to 500/~m, respectively) and for cylindrical pellets of 4 mm length and 4.5 mm diameter as well. Table 4 shows the THF selectivity and the overall DMS conversion rate at low dimethyl succinate conversions of 0.10 to 0.14. The data clearly show that the results obtained with the sieve fraction 210 to 500 mm are not influenced by pore diffusion effects. Only for the much larger catalyst pellets can a significant decrease of reaction rate (corresponding to an effectiveness factor of around 50%), and an increase of tetrahydrofuran selectivity be observed. 3.2. It can be seen that the observations are correctly represented by the solid lines calculated with the parameters given in Table 5. Comparison of the values for parameter k12 (Table 5) for catalysts D and E shows that addition of zinc oxide to copper chromite enhances the activity for the hydrogenolysis of dimethyl succinate. More importantly, especially at higher DMS conversions, the reaction seems to be no longer inhibited by water (parameter b) over the mechanical ZnO/copper chromite mixture. The strong decrease in surface area after exposure to DMS (Table 2) shows that zinc oxide interacts with dimethyl succinate. Thus it can only be suspected that zinc oxide powder provides additional adsorption sites in the vicinity of the active copper sites. In contrast to the copre- cipitated copper catalysts C and F, neither a parallel reaction from DMS to THF (k13), nor the steam reforming of methanol (ks), occurs over the mechanical mixture (catalyst E). When attention is focused on the subsequent conversion of GBL to THF (k23), copper chromite seems to be most active for this reaction, while all other catalysts are relatively similar. To confirm this, the hydrogenation of y-butyrolactone was studied separately. 3.3. In all cases, catalysts previously subjected to dimethyl succinate hydrogenolysis were used. Fig. 9 shows the product distribution as a function of GBL conversion over copper on silica (catalyst A). In contrast to the results obtained during DMS hydrogenolysis, n- butanol is now formed in substantial amounts, most probably according to the following stoichiometric equation. ~H2--CH2~'O 3 I-] 2 ~ CH3--(CH2)3"-OH + I-I20 (17) CHo_CO / + T. The butanol selectivities are in the range of 0.2 (copper chromite) to 0.4 (copper on silica, copper zinc oxide). Since selectivities are not dependent on conversion, butanol must be formed in a parallel reaction over all catalysts studied. This was confirmed by feeding a hydrogen/tetrahydrofuran mixture over copper chromite. Under the reaction conditions of interest, no butanol was formed from THF. Measurements of copper surface area after the reaction showed that the hydro- genation of GBL does not further alter the catalyst properties. Fig. 10 shows the overall area specific rate based on the amount of GBL consumed as a function of the T-butyrolactone conversion. Copper chromite is more active than copper on silica and copper zinc oxide (catalyst C) as is expected from the values of the rate constants k23 given in Table 5. Butanol selectivities are between 0.2 and 0.4 in the case of the separate GBL hydrogenation, while only traces of butanol could be detected during the reaction of dimethyl succinate. It was shown by admixture of methanol or DMS to the GBL feed, that DMS causes the change in butanol selectivity. Reaction data obtained over copper chromite at GBL conversions below 10% reveal that the addition of 50 mol-% methanol does not alter the catalyst activity and selectivity. On the other hand, the presence of 20 mol-% DMS in the reaction mixture drastically decreases the butanol selectivity from 0.22 to a value of 0.06, while the overall DMS con- version rate is slightly decreased from 0.34/zmol m -2 s- 1 to 0.24 mmol m -z s- lo Thus DMS seems to block hydrogenation sites which allow conversion of 3/- butyrolactone to butanol. 4. Conclusions ( 1 ) The course of the reaction during the gas-phase hydrogenolysis of dimethyl succinate over copper chromite, copper on silica, and also over Raney copper previously investigated [6,7], can be explained on the basis of a set of two con- secutive reactions. Firstly the hydrogenolysis of dimethyl succinate to form 3'- butyrolactone and methanol, and secondly the hydrogenation of 7-butyrolactone to tetrahydrofuran and water. T. Turek et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 116 (1994) 137-150 149 (2) Coprecipitated copper zinc oxide catalysts have been shown to exhibit a significantly different behaviour from other copper catalysts. Tetrahydrofuran is mainly formed via a parallel reaction directly from DMS. Additionally, the steam reforming of methanol to carbon dioxide is observed. The rate of dimethyl succinate conversion per unit surface area of copper is up to one order of magnitude higher than over the other copper catalysts studied, while the rate of the secondary hydro- genation of 7-butyrolactone seems to be relatively similar over all catalysts. An increase of catalytic activity by use of zinc oxide addition to copper catalysts was also found in the case of the related direct hydrogenation of maleic anhydride to GBL and THF [ 25 ] and, very recently, during the hydrogenolysis of methyl acetate [26]. (3) The activity of copper chromite for the conversion of dimethyl succinate was enhanced by admixture with zinc oxide. However, in contrast to the coprecip- itated copper zinc oxide catalysts, the gain in activity over the mechanical mixture seems to originate primarily from reduced inhibition by water. This observation could be explained by the generation of additional adsorption sites near the active copper sites. Furthermore, no parallel reaction to tetrahydrofuran and no methanol steam reforming could be detected using the zinc oxide/copper chromite mixture. Further investigations will be required to clarify the exact role of zinc oxide in catalysts used to promote the hydrogenolysis of succinates. (4) In contrast to the results obtained during the hydrogenolysis of dimethyl succinate, formation of butanol was observed to a considerable extent when the hydrogenation of y-butyrolactone was carried out separately. It has been shown that the presence of DMS in the reaction mixture prevents butanol formation, probably by blocking stronger hydrogenation sites. 5. Using copper chromite and copper on silica, γ-butyrolactone (GBL) and methanol were formed in the first step, while GBL reacted further to tetrahydrofuran (THF) and water.
